executive_summary: Over the five years to 2020, the housing market has stabilized while housing starts have slowed, limiting growth opportunities for operators in the Furniture Store Franchises industry. Although residential construction exhibited rapid expansion during the previous five-year period, demand from this construction market has tempered in recent years due to satiated demand, thus limiting demand for upgraded furniture and other cosmetic household items. As a result of slowed growth over the past five years and a sharp decline amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, revenue for the Furniture Store Franchises industry is expected to decline at an annualized rate of 0.4% over the five years to 2020, reaching $2.4 billion.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the five years to 2020, the housing market has stabilized while housing starts have slowed, limiting growth opportunities for operators in the Furniture Store Franchises industry. Although residential construction exhibited rapid expansion during the previous five-year period, demand from this construction market has tempered in recent years due to satiated demand, thus limiting demand for upgraded furniture and other cosmetic household items. As a result of slowed growth over the past five years and a sharp decline amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, revenue for the Furniture Store Franchises industry is expected to decline at an annualized rate of 0.4% over the five years to 2020, reaching $2.4 billion.

In recent years, many specialized retailers have contended with heightened competition from online retailers and big-box stores that can sell furniture at a lower price. To combat this source of competition and to attract more customers, many industry operators have increased wage expenditure to attract more specialized employees that are able to help meet customers' needs, providing additional service. In addition, industry retailers have slashed prices to remain competitive with these other industries. As a result, profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, has declined over the past five years, reaching 3.0% of industry revenue in 2020.

Furniture stores, including franchises, have experienced immense pressure in demand during the coronavirus pandemic's resulting recession as consumers have limited their spending due to economic uncertainty and the spike in the unemployment rate. In particular, consumers have refrained from making large discretionary purchases, such as upholstered furniture. However, benefiting the industry, in response to the coronavirus pandemic, many companies have shifted their employees to remote work, resulting in many individuals and household consumers increasing spending on home office furniture.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2025, the Furniture Store Franchises industry is expected to recover slowly from the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic that struck the industry in 2020. As establishments reopen and as home improvement expenditures resume, industry revenue is expected to increase at an annualized rate of 2.2% over the five years to 2025, reaching $2.7 billion. Despite a rapid return to residential construction over the next five years, consumers are expected to be wary about making large discretionary purchases.

Despite recovering from the coronavirus pandemic, the industry is expected to continue to experience competitive pressures, keeping profit below pre-pandemic levels. As online retail and big-box retailers continue to rise in popularity, industry operators are anticipated to cut prices to remain competitive. Furthermore, industry operators are expected to increase wage expenditure to provide additional service to customers, a competitive advantage over online shopping and mass merchandisers that typically lack specialized customer service and interior design assistance for furniture shopping. As a result, industry profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to account for 3.8% of industry revenue in 2025, up from 3.0% in 2020.

industry_definition: The Furniture Store Franchises industry primarily engages in retailing furniture through physical store locations (as opposed to online sales). Industry revenue is generated through sales of office, home and outdoor furniture. This industry excludes establishments that sell furniture as a secondary source of income.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - steady

key_trends: The Furniture Stores Franchises industry's contribution to the economy is expected to grow in line with US GDP over the 10 years to 2025
There is a widespread market acceptance for industry products
The industry experiences little technological change

products_and_services.product_or_service: Upholstered Furniture, Couches and Dual-Purpose Pieces
Other Accessories, Including Pillows and Linen

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Disposable income largely affects consumer purchasing power to make large discretionary purchases, such as furniture.
The industry is fairly sensitive to fluctuations in spending on home improvements as many consumers upgrade furniture and major appliances during other renovations.
Consumer confidence measures the overall sentiment of the economic outlook. Fluctuations in consumer confidence can influence consumer spending on large household items, such as furniture.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are the largest purchase for industry operators, accounting for an estimated 49.8% of industry revenue in 2020. In 2020, the price of sawmill lumber is expected to surge due to an increase in construction demand while producers have not been able to ramp up production proportionately. As a result, industry operators have had to contend with an increase in purchase costs. Despite the rising input costs, furniture franchises have continued to contend with tempered demand, so many companies have absorbed price hikes in an attempt to attract more customers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.
